SEARCH

Package com.oblong.jelly

package com.oblong.jelly
Jelly's public API to interact with remote pools is contained, in its totallity, in this package.

As a matter of fact, you can build a fully functional jelly application by using Pool's methods to connect to pools and obtain Hose instances allowing you to exchange Protein objects with remote servers. Proteins can be deconstructed into their constituent Slaw, from which you can obtain native java objects. Besides the classes above, you'll probably need to take a look at a couple of enumerations, SlawIlk and NumericIlk, to properly handle the many Slaw kinds, and to PoolException to deal with errors.

In some cases, you might find useful a more structured approach to pool addressing (using PoolAddress and PoolServerAddress), and the reification of pool servers, which can be accomplished (via the creation of objects implementing PoolServer interface) using the Pool.getServer(com.oblong.jelly.PoolServerAddress) factory method.

It's also possible to treat errors in a finer-grained way by means of the host of exception classes defined in the library, all of them deriving from PoolException.

Addressing, and connecting to, pools

A pool location if fully given by its URI, a string formed by a scheme, an optional host name, an optional port, and a pool name. When no host name is provided (as in, e.g., "tcp:///a-pool"), "localhost" is used, while 65456 is the default port (thus, the previous URI is equivalent to "tcp://localhost:65456/a-pool"). Note, however, that the scheme part (e.g. "tcp://" or "mem://") is always mandatory, and that you need to specify a host name if you want to include a port number.

Once you know its URI, you can connect to a pool using Pool's participate method, which will give you back a Hose instance, equipped with all that's needed to exchange proteins with a pool.

Pool also contains methods for creating and deleting pools.

If you prefer to to treat pool URIs in a safer way, PoolAddress objects encapsulate and parse them, and allow you to separate the server part of the address as a PoolServerAddress instance. The latter can be used, in turn, to obtain instances of PoolServer, a class reifying pool servers. As noticed before, usage of these classes is optional: you can perform all required operations on pools via string URIs and the static methods in Pool.

Reading and writing proteins

Once you get a Hose instance from either Pool or a PoolServer, exchanging proteins with a pool is just a matter of using Hose's interface. 
   Hose h = null;
   try {
       h = Pool.participate("tcp://imladris/brandywine");
       Protein p = h.next();
       if (p.timestamp() invalid input: '<' THE_END_OF_THE_3RD_AGE) {
           Slaw s = p.ingests();
           String elrondsRing = s.find(Slaw.string("Elrond")).emitString();
           doSomeMagic(elrondsRing);
       } else {
           Slaw descrips = Slaw.list(Slaw.int8(0),
                                     Slaw.string("too late"));
           h.deposit(Slaw.protein(descrips, nil));
       }
   } catch (PoolException e) {
       tellMithrandir(e);
   } finally {
       if (h != null) h.withdraw();
   }

The above code snippet, despite being silly, illustrates an important point to keep in mind when using jelly: Hose instances, when created, allocate resources, such as network connections, that you want to release, explicitly, as soon as you know that you won't need them anymore. To that end, one calls Hose.withdraw() on the hose; note how the code above makes sure that this method is called even in the presence of errors.

A second important thing to note is that Hose is the only not thread-safe class in the library, since it has mutable state and does not use synchronization primitives internally. If you need to read from a hose only those proteins matching a fixed list of descrips, the FilteredHose decorator may come in handy.

Gangs: multiplexed protein reading

invalid reference 
com.oblong.jelly.HoseGang
maintains a list of named connections to pools, multiplexing their inputs and providing an interface to read and wait on proteins coming from any of the underlying hoses. As an added boon, this class is thread-safe.

Deconstructing proteins

Protein constitutes the exchange coin with pools. Its a kind of Slaw with attached metadata (an index and timestamp, for instance) and two methods, ingests() and descrips() giving you access to its constituent slawx. Proteins can be either obtained from hoses (using, for instance, Hose.next(com.oblong.jelly.Slaw...) or Hose.nth(long)) or explicitly constructed from other slawx using the factory method Slaw.protein(Slaw,Slaw).

Slaw encompasses all the data types a Slaw can represent (with SlawIlk and NumericIlk playing the part of discriminators), and provides methods to extract that data as native java objects and values, as well as accessing sub-slaw for composite Slaw ilks (such as map or list).

The fact that Slaw is actually a union type means that some of their methods will not be applicable to concrete instances (e.g., one cannot call Slaw.emitString() on a slaw with ilk SlawIlk.MAP).

We have chosen to flag errors caused by calling unsupported operations on Slaw instances by means of an unchecked exception, UnsupportedOperationException. The rationale is that you can always avoid those errors by checking for the Slaw's actual ilk, and there will be many places in your programs where you know the ilk of a given Slaw instance (e.g., by construction), and forcing a try/catch block in such cases seemed unnecessary.

The price of that convenience is of course that you must use Slaw's methods carefully to avoid run-time errors.

Slaw instances are either obtained from proteins or created using the host of static factory methods in Slaw.

Serializing Slaw

Although pools are very useful for communicating proteins from one process to another, and can also be used for storage of proteins, it's also sometimes useful to store proteins (or other slawx) in a traditional file (or perhaps a String or a byte array).

The class SlawIO provides a collection of static methods allowing serialization of Slaw and Protein instances to and from files, strings and byte arrays, in binary and text formats. The first is designed for speed and compactness, while the second is a human-readable rendering of slawx using YAML syntax.

Serialization can be performed in one shot for a list of Slaw, or stepwise, via the SlawReader and SlawWriter interfaces.

The documentation for SlawIO provides more details on the serialization formats and utilities.

Error handling

Errors in pool operations are reported by means of exceptions of a type always deriving from PoolException. That allows to write simple try/catch clauses with a single catcher for PoolException, using PoolException.kind() to discover the error's nature. But you can also catch the different exception types individually, if that's the (perhaps more idiomatic) style that you favour. The documentation of PoolException explains how to work with our exception system.

Other kinds of pool: in-memory pools

TCP is not the only supported scheme. You can also use a pseudo-pool server local to the running JVM that store their proteins in memory. Their URI scheme is "mem". The following code creates a 'mem-pool', opens a connection and writes some proteins to it: 

    Hose h = Pool.participate("mem:///a-mem-pool", null);
    Proteins[] proteins = gimmeProts();
    for (Protein p : proteins) h.deposit(p);
    h.withdraw();
where we have used the two-arguments version of participate, which creates the pool if it doesn't already exist. After the code above is executed, the proteins in the array will be stored in memory and accessable by any other hose using the standard Hose interface. Note that we use an empty hostname (the library will then use "localhost" as a default); you can use any other hostname you want, as long as you use the same URI later on to access the pool. Also, in the current version of jelly, in-memory pools accept ignore any creation options (that's why the second argument in the call to participate is null).

In-memory pools come in handy for testing your applications without needing to establish network connections, but can also help providing local sources of proteins to protein sinks that can be coded abstracting away from the real nature of the server providing the proteins (i.e., taking either a Hose or a URI as inputs).
